definition: Great Ancestor (posthumous title, e.g. for the founder of a dynasty)
highest/greatest/too (much)/very/extremely
ancestor/forefather/grandparents
surname Zu
Ming Taizu, Temple name of first Ming emperor Hongwu 洪武[Hong2 wu3]
Emperor Taizu of Song, posthumous title of the founding Song emperor Zhao Kuangyin 趙匡胤|赵匡胤 (927-976), reigned from 960
posthumous title of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤 (1559-1626), founder and first Khan of the Manchu Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金 (from 1616)
posthumous title of Genghis Khan 成吉思汗[Cheng2 ji2 si1 han2] (1162-1227)

sentences.english: His policy of overseas contacts was generally followed by his successors in Ming Dyn …
sentences.chinese: 明朝後代基本上沿用了太祖的海外交往政策。

sentences.english: The Taizhu Emperor of Liao Dynasty forced the popularization of medical knowledge by imitating that of the Tang Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 遼太祖時期，採用強行推廣唐代醫學知識的操作方式。

sentences.english: There is A Copy of Libai's Poems selected and copied by my great grandfather himself at my home.
sentences.chinese: 我家有一本太祖爺爺自己選編並抄寫的《李白詩鈔》。

sentences.english: This hill, Tomb of Emperor Zhu.
Zhu Yuanzhang, founder of Ming Dynasty, granted it the High Mountain Lu.
sentences.chinese: 明太祖朱元璋還曾封廬山爲“廬嶽”。

sentences.english: A legend in his family says one ancestor used to be a monk and beggar, which is very similar to the deeds of Zhu Yuanzhang, the first emperor of Ming Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 這個傳說與明太祖朱元璋極其相似。

sentences.english: The third contributes to Ming Taizhu promotion to advice.
sentences.chinese: 三是明太祖提倡直言的影響。

definition: posthumous name given to second emperor of a dynasty/King Taejong of Joseon Korea (1367-1422), reigned 1400-1418
Emperor Taizu of Song, posthumous title of the founding Song emperor Zhao Kuangyin 趙匡胤|赵匡胤 (927-976), reigned from 960
Ming Taizu, Temple name of first Ming emperor Hongwu 洪武[Hong2 wu3]
the previous dynasty
the current dynasty
Ming Chengzu, Temple name of third Ming Emperor Yongle 永樂|永乐[Yong3 le4]
Zhu Di, personal name of third Ming Emperor Yongle 永樂|永乐[Yong3 le4]
to found a state/to open a closed country
Sejong the Great or Sejong Daewang (1397-1450), reigned 1418-1450 as fourth king of Joseon or Chosun dynasty, in whose reign the hangeul alphabet was invented
to succeed to a title/to inherit
the late Emperor
the (rightful) emperor/"Son of Heaven" (traditional English translation)
Zhao Kuangyin, personal name of founding Song emperor Song Taizu 宋太祖 (927-976)
Gaozong Emperor, Temple name of the tenth Song Emperor Zhao Gou 趙構|赵构[Zhao4 Gou4] (1107-1187 AD), reigned (1127-1162 AD)
Zhu Yuanzhang, personal name of first Ming dynasty emperor Hongwu 洪武[Hong2 wu3]
Song dynasty (960-1279)/used to distinguish it from 劉宋|刘宋 Song of Southern dynasties (420-479)
